definition: Silver - Derived from the Latin word 'Argentum'.

Substances formed when two or more elements are chemically bonded together in a simple whole number ratio. Examples H2O (Water) and NaCl (Table Salt). Each element does not retain its own identity.
Copper - Derived from the Latin word 'Cuprum'.

The simplest form of matter that retains all of its physical and chemical properties. They consist of only one type of atom. Examples: oxygen (O), hydrogen (H), and iron (Fe).
A pure compound with the chemical formula C2H5OH, commonly found in alcoholic beverages.
Iron - Derived from the Latin word 'Ferrum'.
Mercury - Derived from the Latin word 'Hydrargyrum'.
A mixture that is uniform throughout, such as a saltwater solution or air.
A mixture where the components are not evenly distributed, like oil and water or a salad.
A pure substance, chemically known as C3H8O, often used as a disinfectant or cleaning agent.
Potassium - Derived from the Latin word 'Kalium'.
Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space. It can be classified as either a pure substance or a mixture.
A physical combination of two or more substances where each retains its own identity. If you shake it and it comes apart, then it is a mixture. Examples: include paint or sand and water.
Sodium - Derived from the Latin word 'Natrium'.
A pure substance, often stored as O2 in medical settings.
A mixture consisting of various compounds, often including pigments, solvents, and binders.
Lead - Derived from the Latin word 'Plumbum'.
Made up of only one component and can be classified as either elements or compounds. Examples include gold (Au) and water (H2O).
Antimony - Derived from the Latin word 'Stibium'.

The different forms in which matter can exist, which include gases, liquids, solids, and plasma.
